title: Daniel Hanbury
text:
Daniel Hanbury <a href="Fellow%20of%20the%20Royal%20Society">FRS</a> (11 September 1825 – 24 March 1875) was a <a href="British%20people">British</a> <a href="botanist">botanist</a> and <a href="pharmacologist">pharmacologist</a>. He was an early student of <a href="pharmacognosy">pharmacognosy</a>, the study of the <a href="medicinal">medicinal</a> applications of <a href="nature">nature</a>, principally of <a href="plant">plant</a>s.
Life.
Hanbury was born on 11 September 1825 in <a href="Clapham">Clapham</a>, at that time in <a href="Surrey">Surrey</a>, the eldest son of Daniel Bell Hanbury, a <a href="Quaker">Quaker</a> <a href="pharmacist">pharmacist</a>, and his wife Rachel, "née" Christy. He went to <a href="Clapham%20Grammar%20School">Clapham Grammar School</a> in 1833, and in 1841 started work at his father's firm, <a href="Allen%20%26amp%3B%20Hanbury%27s">Allen & Hanbury's</a> in the <a href="City%20of%20London">City of London</a>. In 1857 he completed his training in <a href="pharmaceutical%20chemistry">pharmaceutical chemistry</a> at the <a href="Pharmaceutical%20Society">Pharmaceutical Society</a>. While there he had come into contact with pharmacist-botanists including <a href="Jacob%20Bell%20%28chemist%29">Jacob Bell</a>, <a href="Jonathan%20Pereira">Jonathan Pereira</a> and <a href="Theophilus%20Redwood">Theophilus Redwood</a>, and had become interested both in botany and in <a href="pharmacognosy">pharmacognosy</a>, the knowledge of medicines, and particularly of their geographical and botanical origins. 
Hanbury never married, was a <a href="vegetarianism">vegetarian</a>, and – like many of his <a href="Victorian%20era">Victorian</a> contemporaries – opposed the use of <a href="alcohol%20%28drug%29">alcohol</a> and <a href="tobacco">tobacco</a>.
He retired from business in 1870, and in 1874, in partnership with the Swiss botanist <a href="Friedrich%20August%20Fl%C3%BCckiger">Friedrich August Flückiger</a>, published his "Pharmacographia". He died on 24 March 1875 in <a href="Clapham">Clapham</a> of <a href="typhoid%20fever">typhoid fever</a>, and was buried in the burial ground of the <a href="Society%20of%20Friends">Society of Friends</a> at <a href="Wandsworth">Wandsworth</a>.
Work.
Hanbury's extensive knowledge of the world's botany was based on years of study, collecting and travel - trips to the <a href="Middle%20East">Middle East</a> and throughout <a href="Europe">Europe</a> were supplemented by extensive correspondence with colleagues throughout the world. He was an essential partner to his brother, <a href="Thomas%20Hanbury">Sir Thomas Hanbury</a>, in selecting specimens for and establishing the <a href="Giardini%20Botanici%20Hanbury">Giardini Botanici Hanbury</a> at <a href="La%20Mortola">La Mortola</a>, now maintained by the <a href="University%20of%20Genoa">University of Genoa</a>. On his death, Sir Thomas donated his brother's entire botanical cabinet collection to <a href="Royal%20Botanic%20Gardens%2C%20Kew">Kew Gardens</a>, where it is now part of the Economic Botany Collection.
Hanbury's first published contribution, in volume 1 of the "Transactions of the <a href="Royal%20Pharmaceutical%20Society">Pharmaceutical Society</a>", was published soon after starting his work. It was followed, regularly, by a stream of articles and papers describing the pharmacological applications of various plants, <a href="insects">insects</a>, and <a href="chemicals">chemicals</a>, and published in such distinguished sources as the "Pharmaceutical Journal" and the "Transactions of the <a href="Linnean%20Society%20of%20London">Linnean Society</a>".
During his career he was president of the <a href="British%20Pharmaceutical%20Conference">British Pharmaceutical Conference</a>, botanical examiner of the Board of Examiners of the Royal Pharmaceutical Society (1860-1872; elected member 1857), and in several other major professional capacities. He was elected a <a href="Fellow%20of%20the%20Royal%20Society">Fellow of the Royal Society</a> in 1867.
In 1858 <a href="Berthold%20Carl%20Seemann">Berthold Carl Seemann</a> named the "<a href="Hanburia%20%28plant%29">Hanburia</a>" genus of South American plants in the <a href="Cucurbitaceae">Cucurbitaceae</a> after him.
